notes.title: About Me
notes.preview: Hi, I'm Max. A human being on planet Earth...
notes.content:
Hi, I'm Max.

I'm a human being living on the impossible-to-exist planet Earth.

I'm 30 circles around the Sun old.

I live in a magical place called Uluwatu with my dog, Fiba.

I started working when I was 8.

My parents worked on film crews, and I helped however I could. My first "career years" were extremely hard, chaotic, and absurdly underpaid.

Since 14, I tried almost every teen and student job available.

Since 18, I've been an entrepreneur and marketer â€” building and working with multi-hundred-million-dollar organizations, mostly in crypto.

I've been in crypto for more than a decade now.

As a believer. A researcher. A user. An investor.

I'm still deeply grateful that it exists. I still believe it can help us build a better future.

But I'd be lying if my awe wasn't mixed with cynicism and tiredness after watching so many scams, incompetence, and endless drama.

You grow up fast in this industry.

My last company, Eight Forces, I exited in 2024.

Since then, I've mostly been experimenting with new product ideas, helping companies build growth systems, managing my capital, and trying to become a better human.

Not necessarily in that order.

I believe there are only two questions that really matter:

How to live a good life?
How to be a good person?

To live a good life, you have to be a good person.

What is "good"?

It's what feels good in your body: warmth, peace, laughter, being with friends, being useful, being appreciated â€” you know it when you feel it.

But nowhere close to feeling good is greed, anger, harming people, lying, cheating, stealing, being mean, overthinking, fearing, obeying blindly, or living in poverty.

None of that feels good in your body.

To know real things, you must feel them.

Intelligence and logic are tools. You only need them to solve quests.

But life is not a quest.

It's an experience.

I try to be humble, chill, caring, reliable, and proactively helpful.

Not perfectly. Just honestly.

I'm grateful to be surrounded by people who try to live the same way.

I'm a foodie.

Honestly, that's my main motivation to travel â€” and sometimes even to leave the house.

I'm also into tea, yoga, Eastern philosophy, and other strange, beautiful things that help me stay grounded.

Recently, I've been upgrading my skills with AI tools.

I work with Cursor, Claude, Comet, n8n, and others.

They allow me, solo, to build apps, automate operations, design systems, and multiply content and distribution by 10xâ€“100x.

But building solo is not as much fun as building with smart, ambitious, like-minded people.

So if you're one of them, let's chat.

notes.title: Wins & Fails
notes.content:
Chronological. Honest. No spin.

Every project taught me something. Some lessons cost more than others.

Attention Labs (2025-Present)

Growth and strategy work: applying business fundamentals that have worked for a century, supercharged with AI tools. The goal is simple: help teams do 10-100x more without burning out.

What's working: Built frameworks that actually stick. Integrated AI into real workflows (not just demos). Helped teams move faster while staying sane.

What's still messy: Early days. Still experimenting. Still figuring out how to explain what we do without sounding like everyone else.

The lesson: Tools matter. But thinking clearly matters more.

Quid (2024-2025)

Crypto-native card + IBAN built on Hyperliquid. Real product, real demand, real regulatory headaches.

What worked: Strong community from day one. Designed UX that made sense to actual crypto users. Proved there's appetite for this.

What didn't: Underestimated how slow fintech moves. Regulatory complexity ate our speed. Operational overhead was brutal.

The lesson: Fintech isn't a product problem. It's legal, ops, and patience - mostly patience.

Eight Forces (2023-2024)

Web3 growth agency. Worked with projects that raised tens of millions and hit 9 - figure valuations.

What worked: Record campaigns. Real results. Strong reputation.

What didn't: Scaling culture is hard. Burnout was a real risk - for me and the team.

The lesson: Systems scale. Chaos doesn't. No matter how smart the chaos is.

Intropia (2021-2023)

Decentralized recruitment platform. Solo founder. Built a network of hundreds of top crypto people.

What worked: Raised from great angels. Built something real. Created genuine community.

What didn't: Never cracked monetization. Timing was off.

The lesson: Being early feels like being smart. Until you realize you're just waiting.

Frontrunners / Make It in Ukraine (2018-2021)

Recruitment agency connecting EU/US companies with Ukrainian talent. Built a strong reputation with major tech companies.

What worked: Great clients. Good revenue. Real impact on people's careers.

What didn't: Services hit a ceiling. Hard to scale without breaking quality.

The lesson: Service businesses trade time for money. That's not leverage.

BHSL Community (2019-2022)

Weekly founder breakfasts in Kyiv. Started as an experiment, became a real community that's still running.

What worked: Genuine relationships. No agenda. People kept showing up.

What didn't: Never monetized it.

The lesson: Not everything needs to make money. Some things are just worth doing.

Robonomics (2020-2021)

IoT meets blockchain. CMO role. Took it from $4M to $80M market cap.

What worked: Massive attention. Boston Dynamics integration. Story that resonated.

What didn't: Market volatility hit hard.

The lesson: Great narrative + real tech = force multiplier. But you can't control the market.

Sustainable Rentals (2019-2020)

Eco - friendly rental business. Happy customers, strong brand, bad unit economics.

The lesson: Loving what you do doesn't mean it'll make money.

Custom Paintings (2018-2019)

Personalized art e - commerce. Good revenue, loyal customers, seasonal ceiling.

The lesson: Know your ceiling before you hit it.

Byzantium (2017-2019)

One of the top crypto agencies during the ICO era. Co - founded it. Helped raise $150M+.

What worked: Major clients. Industry reputation. Real momentum.

What didn't: Markets crash. They always do eventually.

The lesson: Reputation is the only asset that survives cycles.

Humanic ICO (2016-2017)

Marketing Director. Raised ~5,000 BTC. Built every channel myself.

The lesson: Full - stack marketing - where you understand the whole machine - wins.

MaxUp Agency (2013-2015)

Traditional marketing agency. HVAC clients. Stable revenue. Taught myself how to sell.

The lesson: Sales builds confidence. Everything else is easier after you learn to sell.

B2B Marketing Course (2020-2021)

Wrote and taught a deep professional course. Thousands of students. Industry recognition.

The lesson: Teaching forces clarity. Clarity scales impact.

notes.title: Frameworks
notes.preview: Things I actually use. Not theory, practice...
notes.content:
Things I actually use. Not theory, practice.

How I Launch Products

I start with users, not decks.

Find people who care. Build community around the problem. Figure out distribution. Then polish the product.

If people don't care early, I stop. Sunk cost is a trap.

How I Think About Leverage

Time is finite. Energy is finite. Money can compound.

I optimize for work that compounds: systems, content, equity. I avoid work that disappears when I stop.

How I Make Decisions

Most decisions are reversible. Move fast on those.

Few decisions are permanent. Slow down for those.

The skill is knowing which is which.

notes.title: Investments & Bets
notes.preview: How someone invests reveals how they think...
notes.content:
I don't share this to flex. I share it because how someone invests reveals how they think.

Where I Started

I grew up in a family where "investing" wasn't a concept. No one ran a business. No one talked about markets. We had apartments inherited from Soviet times. No one knew they were "assets."

My first real investment was Bitcoin in 2016, at $600. Bought it with money I'd earned selling marketing services. That changed everything.

I'd spent two years forming my thesis, reading everything, getting deeply bullish on crypto. The moment I had money to invest, I did.

That early conviction shaped me but also created bias. Over the years I've made absurd amounts of money in crypto and lost much of it. Bad allocation. Trusting the wrong people. Learning expensive lessons.

Through many iterations, I've developed a clearer view of how I want to invest.

Crypto

Still my largest allocation. Still where I have the most conviction and edge.

Bitcoin. The only true alternative asset class. Unlimited liquidity. Censorship-resistant. Full self-custody. I treat it as a long-term store of value, not a trade.

Hyperliquid. My highest-conviction bet outside Bitcoin. It sits at the intersection of the two most profitable niches in crypto: trading infrastructure (taking share from Binance) and Layer 1 blockchains (competing with Ethereum and Solana). Also the first project that feels like an honest alternative to the VC-backed token model.

Solana. Excellent technology, team, and communication. They ship constantly. I've had great trades here and I'm rebuilding my position.

What I avoid. Anything with heavy VC backing and the "low float, high FDV" playbook. These tokens are designed to extract value from retail.

Speculation. I enjoy speculating on current narratives like memecoins and AI agents. But I size these as casino bets, not investments.

Real Estate

After 10 years in crypto, I wanted to diversify into physical assets.

My thesis: real estate isn't always the best return, but it's valuable when you find the right opportunity. I think about it in three categories:

The specific deal. In any market, you can find asymmetric deals if you look. My Bali investment was like this. Bought during construction chaos, waited a year, and now it's appreciating.

The location thesis. I'm bullish on coastal living. Remote work is permanent. Successful people are seeking better climate, communities, and tax environments. I invest where they'll want to live: Bali, Dubai, Madeira.

Early-stage edge. All my real estate investments had a reason to buy now rather than later. Bali during disruption. Dubai during construction, years before completion. Madeira at a very early stage through a well-connected local contact.

I treat real estate like venture: small asymmetric bets with some personal edge in timing, relationships, or taste.

Traditional Assets

Holding cash in dollars means losing money slowly.

I keep a portion in index funds and commodities. Not exciting. That's the point. Stability while other bets play out.

Exploring

Areas I'm interested in but don't have active positions yet:

  • Critical infrastructure
  • Wellness and longevity
  • Medical innovation

Principles

1. Invest in what you understand. My best returns came from crypto because I spent years building conviction first.

2. Size matters. Asymmetric bets should be sized so you can be wrong multiple times and still win overall.

3. People matter. My worst losses came from trusting the wrong people. My best wins came from backing the right ones.

4. Cash is a position. Sometimes the best investment is waiting.

This is how I think today. It'll evolve.

notes.title: Favorite Books
notes.preview: Not a reading list, just books that changed how I think...
notes.content:
Not a reading list, just books that actually changed how I think.

Philosophy & Big Ideas

Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind Â· Yuval Noah Harari

Zooms out far enough to make you rethink what humans actually are and why we organize the way we do.

The Beginning of Infinity Â· David Deutsch

Explanations, progress, and why knowledge creation might be the most important thing humans do.

Tao Te Ching Â· Lao Tzu

The original manual for doing less and achieving more. I return to it constantly.

Human Action Â· Ludwig von Mises

Dense but foundational. How individuals make choices and what that means for economics and society.

Fooled by Randomness Â· Nassim Nicholas Taleb

We confuse luck with skill constantly. This book made me question every success story, including my own.

If you've already read the "popular" philosophy, go deeper: Aristotle, Seneca, Nietzsche.

Spirituality & Consciousness

Siddhartha Â· Hermann Hesse

A journey toward meaning that doesn't preach, just shows.

Inner Engineering Â· Sadhguru

Practical tools for inner work. Less mystical than you'd expect.

Autobiography of a Spiritually Incorrect Mystic Â· Osho

Provocative, contradictory, occasionally brilliant.

Man's Search for Meaning Â· Viktor Frankl

How to find purpose even in the worst circumstances. Short and devastating.

The Sorrows of Satan Â· Marie Corelli

Victorian-era exploration of temptation, success, and what we trade for it.

Psychology & Decision-Making

Misbehaving: The Making of Behavioral Economics Â· Richard Thaler

Why people don't act rationally, and how that changes everything about economics and business.

Thinking, Fast and Slow Â· Daniel Kahneman

The two systems in your brain and why you can't trust your intuitions as much as you think.

The Brain Sell Â· David Lewis

How neuroscience explains buying decisions. Useful for marketing, unsettling for self-awareness.

Habits of a Happy Brain Â· Loretta Breuning

The chemistry behind why we feel what we feel, and how to work with it.

So-Called Evil Â· Konrad Lorenz

Aggression from a biological perspective. Changes how you think about human nature.

Marketing & Influence

The Tipping Point Â· Malcolm Gladwell

How small things become big things. The mechanics of virality before we called it that.

Ogilvy on Advertising Â· David Ogilvy

Timeless advertising wisdom from someone who actually built the industry.

My Life in Advertising Â· Claude Hopkins

Written almost a century ago and still relevant. Proof that marketing fundamentals don't change.

Influence: The Psychology of Persuasion Â· Robert Cialdini

The six principles everyone uses to persuade, whether they know it or not.

Selling the Invisible Â· Harry Beckwith

Marketing services is different. This book gets it.

Marketing Management / Marketing 3.0 Â· Philip Kotler

The textbook foundation, plus the evolution toward values-driven marketing.

Expert Secrets Â· Russell Brunson

How to build movements around ideas. More practical than it sounds.

Narconomics Â· Tom Wainwright

Drug cartels as case studies in supply chain, branding, and market dynamics. Unexpectedly brilliant.

Startups & Business Building

The Lean Startup Â· Eric Ries

Build, measure, learn. The framework that changed how startups think about product development.

Zero to One Â· Peter Thiel

Contrarian thinking about building monopolies and creating real value.

The Four Steps to the Epiphany Â· Steve Blank

Customer development before product development. Still the best framework.

Business Model Generation / The Invincible Company Â· Alexander Osterwalder & Yves Pigneur

Visual frameworks for designing and stress-testing business models.

The Hard Thing About Hard Things Â· Ben Horowitz

What it actually feels like to run a company when everything is going wrong.

The Cold Start Problem Â· Andrew Chen

How network effects actually work and how to kickstart them.

Learning to Build Â· Bob Moesta

Jobs-to-be-done framework in practice. How to build things people actually want.

Product-Led Growth Â· Bush Wes

When the product is the marketing. The playbook for modern SaaS.

Leadership & Management

The Ideal Executive Â· Ichak Adizes

No one person can do it all. How to build complementary leadership teams.

It's Not the How or the What but the Who Â· Claudio FernÃ¡ndez-ArÃ¡oz

Hiring is the highest-leverage activity. This book shows why and how.

Up the Organization Â· Robert Townsend

Irreverent, practical wisdom about running companies without losing your mind.

Who: The A Method for Hiring Â· Geoff Smart & Randy Street

A systematic approach to hiring that actually works.

Tribal Leadership Â· Dave Logan

How company culture forms in stages, and how to level it up.

Fundraising & Growth

Fundraising Â· Ryan Breslow

Modern tactical guide to raising money. No fluff.

Read Write Own Â· Chris Dixon

The case for web3 and user ownership from one of the clearest thinkers in the space.

The Network State Â· Balaji Srinivasan

What comes after nation-states? Ambitious, provocative, worth wrestling with.

People Powered Â· Jono Bacon

Building and scaling communities. The mechanics behind movements.

Productivity & Focus

The ONE Thing Â· Gary Keller & Jay Papasan

Focus on the one thing that makes everything else easier or unnecessary.

The Attention Revolution Â· B. Alan Wallace

Meditation-based attention training. Deeper than most productivity books.

Tools of Titans Â· Tim Ferriss

Tactics, routines, and habits from hundreds of high performers. Good for browsing.

Catching the Big Fish Â· David Lynch

Creativity, meditation, and how ideas actually come. Short and strange in the best way.

Fiction & Literature

Midnight's Children Â· Salman Rushdie

India's history through magical realism. Dense, rewarding, unforgettable.

The Sirens of Titan Â· Kurt Vonnegut

Free will, purpose, and the absurdity of existence, wrapped in sci-fi satire.

The Three-Body Problem Â· Liu Cixin

Hard sci-fi that makes you feel small in the best way. Changed how I think about civilization.

Hard to Be a God Â· Arkady & Boris Strugatsky

What happens when you can't interfere, even when you could help. Soviet-era sci-fi that stays with you.

Still adding to this list. Still learning.

notes.title: Health & Routines
notes.preview: Optimizing for feeling good over decades...
notes.content:
I don't optimize for productivity metrics. I optimize for feeling good and thinking clearly over decades.

Meditation

Daily. Not to achieve anything, just to practice being present.

Movement

Yoga, surfing, walking. Nothing heroic. Just consistent.

Sleep

Protecting it like it's my most valuable asset. Because it is.

Food

Real food. Cooked well. Eaten slowly when possible.

This isn't a system for 10x output. It's a system for not burning out while doing interesting work for a long time.

Overall: Good experience. Would go again.

Africa is still under-explored for me. One day.

Americas

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ United States

I've spent a lot of time in the US.

Lived there. Worked there. Built things there.

Been to: New York. San Francisco. Rhode Island (Newport, Providence). Philadelphia. Denver. Austin. Miami. Los Angeles.

America is special.

You can find anyone and anything here.

In one day in San Francisco, you can see: The richest people on Earth. The poorest people on Earth. The smartest. The dumbest.

Sometimes on the same street.

It's insanely diverse. Economically. Culturally. Mentally.

I love the US.

It's probably not my natural "home vibe". But I could live there.

And if I had to choose one country to spend the rest of my life inâ€¦

It would be the United States.

That says a lot.

ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ Mexico

Mexico surprised me. A lot.

Been to: Mexico City. TeotihuacÃ¡n (pyramids).

I expected: Chaos. Danger. Discomfort.

Got: Safety. Great food. Green streets. Walkable neighborhoods. Friendly people.

CDMX is amazing.

Completely underrated.

I came with zero expectations. Left impressed.

Would happily return.

One of my biggest surprises.

Been to: BogotÃ¡. MedellÃ­n. (Was going to Cartagenaâ€¦ never made it ğŸ˜„)

Stopped in MedellÃ­n. Stayed for months.

It just pulled me in.

Food: amazing. Services: great. Healthcare: solid. Housing: high quality. Prices: low.

Quality of life / cost = insane.

Butâ€¦ Safety is real.

I stayed mostly in: El Poblado. Laureles.

Was advised not to wander too much with laptop / watch / valuables.

You feel the risk.

Still: Colombia is beautiful. People are warm. Country has huge potential.

Respect.
